translated: The Sutra of Ananda's Distinctions Spoken by the Buddha
Translated by the Monk Shi Faxian of the Qifu
Ananda said to the Buddha, Some people who serve the Buddha obtain wealth, nobility, and favorable benefits, while others suffer losses and are not favored. Why are they not equal?
I wish that the Heavenly Among Heavens would explain this for us.
The Buddha told Ananda:
There are people who serve the Buddha, receive precepts from a wise teacher, exclusively believe and do not violate them, diligently uphold and practice them, and do not lose what they have received.
The images are fresh and clear, and they worship in the morning and evening, respectfully lighting lamps.

They provide clean offerings, do not violate the precepts, are not weary of the fasts and precepts, and their minds are always joyful. They are always protected by the heavenly beings and good spirits;
Whatever they encounter is favorable, and a hundred things increase and double. They are respected by the heavenly dragons, spirits, and the masses, and later they will certainly attain Buddhahood.
These are the true disciples of the Buddha, the good men and good women.
There are people who serve the Buddha but do not meet good teachers, do not see the scriptures, and only receive the precepts.
They are shown to have the name of precepts, but are confused and do not believe, violate the precepts, sometimes believe and sometimes do not believe, and their minds are hesitant.
There are no scriptures or images, and since they do not burn incense and make offerings daily, they always harbor anger.
They speak evil words and scold, and do not observe the six days of abstinence, killing with their own hands.
They do not respect the Buddha's scriptures, keeping them in shabby boxes;
Or placing them on the bed with their wives and children;
Or hanging them on the wall, without the intention of making offerings or seats, no different from worldly books.

If they become ill, they doubt and do not believe, then calling shamans to divine and make offerings to evil spirits. The celestial spirits stay far away, unable to provide good protection. Ghosts and demons increase daily, evil spirits gather at the door, causing decline, and whatever they do does not go well.
In this life, sinful people are not disciples of the Buddha. After death, they will enter the hells and be tortured.
Because of their sins, they will experience decline in this life, and later they will suffer retribution. The pain of the departed soul is indescribable.
Foolish people are blind and do not think of their past lives and karmic causes from the past. The spirit goes to its roots and origins, and they say that serving the Buddha leads to this decline.
They are not ashamed of their own past unwholesome actions, but blame the sages and heavens. Worldly people are confused and do not understand to this extent.

Those who do not understand are suspicious and indecisive, their faith is not firm, their minds are unsettled, and they lose their principles in advancing and retreating. They betray the Buddha's kindness and are not grateful, and thus they are bound by the three paths, creating their own calamities and blessings.

The causes of sinful consciousness, planted and obtained from the roots, cannot be disobeyed. The ten wholesome paths are thick friends, and the peace of the spirit and attainment of the Way all arise from goodness.
One who dons the great armor, is not afraid of weapons, and can uphold their word, will have peace and blessings in their home, bestowed naturally, not given by the gods.
If one still does not believe now, their future rebirths will be even more difficult!
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!
Good and evil pursue people, like a shadow following a form, and cannot be escaped.
The matters of sin and merit are all like this. Do not give rise to doubt and fall into the evil paths yourself!
If one has sincere faith and is not deluded, they will always be at ease wherever they are. The Buddha's words are sincere and will never deceive people.
The Buddha further told Ä€nanda:

The Buddha does not speak two different things. The sutra Dharma is difficult to hear. You have blessings from past lives and now serve the Buddha. You should remember to repay your kindness, spread the Dharma teachings, show them to the people, and be a field of merit for them. Those who have faith will encounter it, and have no worries in their future rebirths.
Ä€nanda accepted the teachings and widely spread them as instructed.
Ä€nanda further addressed the Buddha, saying:
If a person does not kill with their own hands, but instructs others to kill, is it then not a crime?
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!
Instructing others to kill is graver than killing oneself.
Why is this?
It may be that the servant, fool, or lowly person does not understand the law of offenses;

Or they may be compelled by the county officials to carry out the orders, not acting out of their own intention. Although they incur the crime, the circumstances and intentions differ, with varying degrees of severity.
Instructing others to kill, one knowingly commits the offense, harboring a sinister intent to harm, turning to a fool or evil person, without any compassionate heart;
Deceiving the Three Jewels, one also naturally commits the five heinous crimes, harming a living being or a person, the offense is no greater!
Resentment and retribution, suffering the consequences for generations, revolving and repaying each other, without end.

In the present life, they are not at ease, often encountering disasters and misfortunes. After death, they enter hell. Even if they escape from the human form, they will fall into the animal realm, where they will be slaughtered by people. In the three evil paths and eight difficulties, for millions and millions of eons, they will provide meat for people, with no end in sight.

Causing their bodies to suffer, eating grass and drinking from springs. In this world, there are currently these kinds of animals, all due to their past lives when they were human. They were violent and rebellious, without principles. They secretly harmed and injured living beings, and did not believe in this. From generation to generation, they became enemies and took revenge on each other. The spirits are the same, but the forms are different. The sins are as deep as this.
Ä€nanda again addressed the Buddha, saying:
If people in the world and the Buddha's disciples harbor evil intentions towards their teachers and those of moral virtue, what are their offenses?
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
As a human being, one should love and enjoy the goodness of others, and take the good as friends. One should not be jealous of them.
If one has evil intentions towards a virtuous person or a good teacher, it is no different from having evil intentions towards the Buddha.
It would be better to hold a crossbow with a thousand-pound trigger and shoot oneself.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
Does shooting oneself hurt?
Ä€nanda said:
It hurts very much, it hurts very much!
World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
The pain of someone holding evil intentions towards a virtuous person or their teacher is worse than being shot by a crossbow.

As a disciple, one should not be disrespectful to their teacher, and should not have evil intentions towards virtuous people. They should be regarded as Buddhas and one should not be jealous of their goodness.
Those who have the precepts and virtue can move the gods, and the heavenly dragons and spirits all respect and honor them.
It would be better to throw oneself into a fire or cut one's flesh with a sharp knife, but one should never be jealous of others' goodness, as the sin is not small.ğŸ”½Be careful!
Be careful!
Ä€nanda said:
Is it not so that a teacher is one who can truly not be a disciple?
Is it possible to turn a small offense into a great one, or to have no offense?
The Buddha said:
It is not possible!
It is very profound, very profound!
The meaning of teacher and disciple is naturally felt, and after they have agreed to be so, they should regard each other as themselves;
What they do not wish for themselves, they should not impose on others. They should uphold the precepts and not engage in disputes. Disciples should also be like this.

If the two meanings are sincere, the teacher should be like a teacher, and the disciple should be like a disciple. They should not slander each other, and should be careful not to harbor poison. Small grudges can grow into great ones and burn oneself.

I observe that in the latter age, there are evil people and demonic monks who only think of others' faults and do not stop their own evil. They are jealous of the virtuous and resentful of the good, not thinking of practicing the Way. Since they themselves cannot do it, they also destroy others, cutting off their resolve for the Way and preventing them from practicing.
If you greedily pursue worldly affairs, accumulate wealth, and destroy yourself, you will fall into the great hells after death. This should not be so.
What do you seek in the world?

Remember the Buddha's kindness and lead each other to the Way. The Way should not be neglected. It can save the spirit, free from suffering, transcend birth and death, and see the wise without arrogance. Do not slander the good. Do not use small faults to prove the great crimes of great people. Violating the Dharma and losing reason, its crime is no greater.
The evidence of sin and merit, should it not be taken seriously?
Ä€nanda again said to the Buddha:
In the final age, disciples who manage affairs due to circumstances, how should they act according to their convenience?
The Buddha said:
Accept the Buddha's precepts, believe and practice them, do not think of deception, and be respectful and cautious.
Respectfully take refuge in the Three Jewels, and serve one's parents with utmost loyalty. One may do worldly affairs, but not worldly intentions.
Ä€nanda said:
What are worldly affairs and worldly intentions?
God among Gods!
The Buddha said:

As a disciple of the Buddha, one may engage in profitable occupations, using a fair scale and honest measures without deceiving the people, conducting oneself reasonably without violating natural principles.
Funerals, moving, marriage - these are worldly affairs.

As for worldly matters, disciples of the Buddha should not engage in divination, seek omens, use talismans and spells, practice sorcery, make sacrifices, or perform rituals. They should not choose auspicious times or days.
Those who accept the Buddha's five precepts are people of merit and virtue. In all their undertakings, they should inform the Three Jewels;
the protection of the Way is strong. Even the various heavens, dragons, ghosts, and spirits all respect and submit to it.
When the precepts are valued, one is honored, and there is no place that is not auspicious. How could there be taboos or inauspicious things?

Unenlightened people create their own curses. Good and evil events are created by the mind. Calamities and blessings come from oneself, like a shadow following a form or an echo responding to a sound.
The virtue of precepts and conduct is naturally in accord with it. Protected by the gods, may your wishes not be violated. It moves the ten directions, and your virtue is equal to that of the gods.
Your merits and virtues are lofty, and the multitude of sages praise you, difficult to fathom!
The wise understand life and death, and do not go astray until the end of their lives. Being good as the Buddha teaches, one can attain the path to liberation from the world.
When Ä€nanda heard what the Buddha said, he straightened his kasaya robe and touched his head to the ground, saying:
Yes, World-Honored One!
We have blessings and have met the TathÄgata. Your universal kindness and compassion pity all, acting as a field of merit, enabling us to escape suffering.
The Buddha said:
Those who truly believe are few. In this world, there are many evils. Sentient beings curse each other, which is very painful!
If there are believers, like one or two, how can the evils of the world be so rampant?
After the Buddha's extinction, the sutra Dharma will gradually decline and disappear!ğŸ”½Alas!
How painful!
What can we rely on?
Ä€nanda shed tears and said due to the matter:
The Buddha is the protector of the three realms, his kindness is vast and his compassion is universal,
In this defiled world, not seeing the Buddha, it is also difficult to encounter the Dharma.
Alas, those who do not recognize, blind and blind, do not distinguish the true,
Alas, it is like this, sins make one act like this.
Those with past blessings who encounter the Dharma, whether one or two,
The scriptures are gradually disappearing, what can we rely on again?
The Buddha's kindness is not small, but due to the beings' sins,
The Dharma drum shakes the three thousand worlds, why can't it be heard?
In this turbid world, there are many evil people, with inverted views, falling into perversion,
Flattering and slandering the sages, with crooked flattery, mutually destroying each other.
They do not believe that there is a Buddha in the world, saying that the Buddha is not the great way,
These people are non-humans, creating the root of many sins themselves.
When life ends, one goes to AvÄ«ci, where swords and knives sever the body,ğŸ”½Hungry ghosts who delight in killing and plundering, boiling cauldrons rise up within them,
The licentious embrace copper pillars, great fires burn them,
Slandering and defaming pure and lofty people, iron hooks pull out their tongues.
Disorderly drinking without propriety, deluded and lost in the human path,
After death, one enters the hells, molten copper is poured into their mouths,
Encountering many perilous difficulties, the poisonous pain is indescribable,
If reborn as a human, one is born into a lowly and poor family.
Not killing leads to long life, without illness one is always healthy,
Not stealing leads to great wealth later, money and wealth are always abundant,
Not engaging in sexual misconduct leads to pure fragrance, the body is fresh and fragrant,
Light and shadow are always radiant, one becomes the king of the heavens above.
Being sincere and not deceitful, one is revered by the multitude,
Not understanding the later clarity, the virtue and wisdom are what are respected.
The five blessings surpass the Dharma and emerge, the heavens and humans are of the same kind,
The births are millions of times, the true meaning is very clear.
In the latter age, the evil people do not believe and have many doubts,
The foolish and ignorant do not distinguish the Way, the deep sins then reach the darkness,
Obscuring the sages and defaming the Right Enlightenment, after death they enter the great iron city,
The consciousness resides within, with an iron wheel on the head.
Seeking death but not being able to die, in an instant the form changes,
The spears and halberds pierce each other, the body is always mutilated.
How can the world be like this? Turning away from the Right and believing in ghosts and spirits,
Understanding the good divination and questioning, sacrificing and injuring the unkind,
After death, they fall into the eighteen hells, experiencing the black-string hell,
The eight difficulties are at the head of the realm, it is difficult to regain a human body.
If one is born as a human, among barbarians with no sense of right and wrong,
Foolish and ignorant, crippled and lame, unable to speak,
Confused and unable to understand things, dragged around by evil karma.
Transmigrating through various groups, taking the form of birds and beasts, or the six domestic animals,ğŸ”½Being slaughtered by humans, skinned alive, their throats cut,
Returning to repay past grudges, giving back flesh to humans,
Falling into evil paths due to lack of virtue, it is extremely difficult to escape.
The human body is difficult to obtain, and the Buddha's teachings are difficult to hear,
The World-Honored One is the benefactor, the most honored one in the three realms,
Spreading the sweet dew Dharma, causing everyone to practice it.
Alas, having already attained wisdom, out of compassion for sentient beings,
Explaining and revealing the true path, the wise ones are immediately liberated from suffering.
The fortunate ones are in the stages of seeing the truth and learning, accomplishing the path,
Taking refuge in the great field of protection, planting seeds in the ground of immortality.
Compassion and kindness surpass this, the world's benefactor turning the Dharma wheel,
Wishing to cause all people to drink the nectar,
The ship of wisdom reaching the other shore, the Dharma bell leading the trichiliocosm,
Self and other are not two, vowing to give rise to the unsurpassed true [mind].
